div.l: And seid his tale as ye shall aftre her͗e
Here endeth þe Prolog of þe Cokes tale /

And next bigynneth
Þe Cokes tale of þe Prentise of london̄
A prentise dwelled whilom in our͗e Cite
Of a craft of vvitelers was he
Gailer he was as goldfinche in þe schawe
Broun̄ as a berie and a propre felawe
With lokkes blak and kemed fetously
Daunce he couth wel and pretely
Þat he was cleped ꝑperkyn reueloᵘr͗e
He was ful of loue ⁊and ꝑparamour͗e
As is þe hony combe of hony swete
Wel ware þe wenche þat might him mete
For whan þer͗e ony riding was in chepe
Oute of þe shopp þedre wold he lepe
Til he had þat sight seyn̄
And daunce wele he nold not torne a yene
And gadered him a mēnyȝe of his sorte
To hopp and syng and make disporte
And þer͗e þey sitten̄ steven for͗e to mete
To pley atte dice in such a strete
For in þe town was þer͗e no such prentise
Þat fairer coude cast a paire of dice
Þen ꝑperken couth and þer͗e to he was free
Of his dispence in place or privite
That fand his mast̉er wel in his chaffar͗e
For oft tyme he founde his box all bar͗e
For swych a prentise revelloure
Þat haunteth dice revell or ꝑparamour͗e
His maister shall yit yit in his shop aby
Whan no ꝑparte of þe mylstralcy
For theft and riot be confortable
All can þey pley on þe gyterne ⁊and rable
Revel and trott as in a lowe degre
Þei ben̄ ful wrothe al day as ye may se
Þis Ioly prentise with his mast̉er bode
Til he was ny oute / of his prentishode
All wer͗e he snebbed both erely ⁊and late
And som̄ tyme led with revell to Newgate
But atte last þis maister hīm bithought
Vpon a day whan he his pepper sought
Of a proverbe þat seith þis same worde
Well bet is roten appell oute of horde
